items.about:
WHO ARE WE
ChemReclaim is a nanotechnology startup redefining how high-performance materials are engineered. We specialize in advanced nanopowders and nanocoatings made from precious metals and rare-earth metal oxides for cutting-edge industries.
Founded with a passion for scientific rigor and sustainable innovation, we operate at the intersection of materials science, performance, and circularity.

WHAT DO WE DO
We design and produce customizable nanopowders and nanocoatings with tightly controlled purity, particle size, and surface chemistry. Our materials are built for critical applications in hydrogen technologies, semiconductors, aerospace, catalysis, and advanced ceramics - where consistency, reliability, and functionality are essential.

Our solutions enable up to 5–40x reductions in critical metal usage, without compromising performance. 
This is how we help our partners achieve more - with less.

WHY DO WE DO IT
Strategic and high-tech industries face rising pressure from critical metal scarcity, supply chain volatility, and surging demand fueled by the green transition. Mining alone won’t close the gap and recycling requires time. 
We believe smarter, more efficient use of critical materials is key to building a resilient and sustainable future.

At ChemReclaim, we're committed to enabling innovation without environmental compromise.
items.name: ChemReclaim
items.tagline: Nano powders and coatings from critical metals. Built for precision and superior performance

items.about:
Whisper is a predictive cybersecurity company providing a platform that offers a real-time, comprehensive view of the internet's infrastructure to anticipate cyber threats before they occur. The company was founded in January 2025 by CEO Leonardo Carlo Calisse, CTO Kaveh Ranjbar, and CPO/CIO Soroush Rafiee Rad. The founding team combines experience in startup growth, internet governance, and mathematics. Ranjbar is a recognized internet leader, having served as CIO of RIPE NCC and as a board member at ICANN, while Rafiee Rad holds two PhDs in mathematics and complex systems. 

Whisper emerged from the Antler venture capital firm's fall 2024 program, securing pre-seed funding from among 8,000 startups. In July 2025, the company announced it had raised €1.6 million in a pre-seed funding round led by Atlas AI^VB Fund I, with participation from Antler, D11Z, Tioga Trust, and Volve Capital. This capital is intended to support expansion into Europe and the US, as well as to grow its technology and sales teams. 

The company's core technology utilizes a knowledge graph to map over 45 billion data points from 18 source types, including IPs, domains, and routing data, updating in near real-time. This system, which the company refers to as a "God Mode" view, allows it to detect malicious infrastructure and hidden relationships, providing predictive intelligence to stop multi-vector, AI-driven attacks. Whisper's platform aims to reduce false positives through multi-parameter scoring and provide context behind threats. The service is designed for a range of clients, including cybersecurity providers who can integrate the data via APIs, government and defense agencies for detecting digital espionage, and enterprises seeking to manage cyber risks. Since its launch, Whisper has secured pilot projects with other cybersecurity providers. 

Keywords: predictive cybersecurity, knowledge graph, threat intelligence, internet infrastructure mapping, real-time threat detection, attack surface management, cyber risk, network security, malicious infrastructure, pre-attack intelligence, multi-vector attacks, cybersecurity APIs, national security, digital espionage, proactive security
items.name: Whisper
items.tagline: Predictive cybersecurity platform mapping real-time internet infrastructure

items.about:
Visualise.bio is a company focused on making high-resolution 3D imaging more accessible and reliable by standardizing expansion microscopy (ExM).

The company was co-founded by a team that includes Floris van der Staaij (CEO), Josiah Passmore (Head of Science), Lukas Kapitein (Scientific Advisor), and Hugo Damstra. The foundational GelMap technology was developed in the laboratory of co-founder Professor Dr. Lukas Kapitein. A significant milestone was the signing of a license agreement with Utrecht Holdings in October 2024 to commercialize this GelMap technology. In November 2024, the company secured $376K in an early-stage venture funding round from investor Innovatiefonds Noord-Holland. 

Visualise.bio addresses the challenge of standardizing expansion microscopy through automation and quality control solutions. The business serves researchers and scientists in fields like pathology and diagnostics who require detailed and reproducible 3D imaging. The market is centered around biological research that utilizes advanced microscopy data. Revenue is likely generated through the sale of its hardware and software products.

The company's core products are GelCast and GelMap. GelCast is a sample processing robot that fully automates the expansion microscopy workflow, from sample input to gel output, using a well-plate format to increase throughput and reliability without manual intervention. GelMap provides a crucial quality control standard by introducing a fluorescent grid into hydrogels before expansion. This feature allows for the accurate measurement of local expansion factors and corrects for any deformations, ensuring the resulting images are precise and reproducible. This represents a tenfold improvement in resolution over standard confocal microscopy. Keywords: expansion microscopy, 3D imaging, automated microscopy, biological data visualization, high-resolution imaging, GelCast, GelMap, laboratory automation, life sciences, biotechnology, pathology diagnostics, scientific instruments, hydrogel, fluorescence microscopy, data reliability, research tools, Utrecht Holdings, Innovatiefonds Noord-Holland, Lukas Kapitein, Floris van der Staaij
items.name: Visualise.Bio
items.tagline: Biological research with 3D visualisation and analysis tools for microscopy data

items.about:
Antfarm is a technology firm focused on enhancing the efficiency of recycling operations through the deployment of AI-powered robotics. The company was founded in December 2023 by Misha Laskin and Francesco Ferrari, both of whom bring extensive experience from the autonomous vehicle sector, having previously worked at Waymo.

The core of Antfarm's offering is an AI-driven robotic system designed to be retrofitted onto existing conveyor belts within material recovery facilities (MRFs). This system utilizes a robotic arm to identify and sort valuable materials, such as used beverage cans, from the waste stream. The primary objective is to increase the volume of recycled materials captured, thereby improving the profitability and operational efficiency of these facilities.

Antfarm operates on a robotics-as-a-service (RaaS) business model. Instead of an upfront capital expenditure for the machinery, clients pay a monthly fee for the sorting services provided by the robots. This model is structured to be profitable for the client from the outset, as Antfarm only generates revenue when the value of the materials recovered by its robots exceeds the service fee. The company targets operators of material recovery facilities as its primary client base, addressing the critical need to improve sorting accuracy and reduce the amount of valuable material that ends up in landfills.

In May 2024, Antfarm announced it had secured $4.8 million in a seed funding round. This financing was led by notable venture capital firms and angel investors, providing the capital to further develop its technology and expand its operational footprint within the recycling industry. 
Keywords: recycling robotics, AI sorting, material recovery facilities, waste management technology, robotics-as-a-service, cleantech, circular economy, computer vision, industrial automation, sustainable technology

items.about:
Movanta is a Dutch clean energy company that specializes in converting wet organic waste into renewable biofuels. Leveraging its proprietary Hydrothermal Upgrading (HTU) technology, the company transforms biomass streams such as sewage sludge, agricultural residues, and food industry waste into high-quality biofuels, including biodiesel and sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). This innovative process operates under high pressure and temperature in a water-rich environment, breaking down complex organic materials into a biocrude oil that can be refined using conventional methods.
What sets Movanta apart is its ability to process waste streams with high water content—materials typically unsuitable for standard biofuel production methods. The HTU technology not only enables the creation of clean energy from waste but also reduces nitrogen emissions by converting nitrogenous compounds into usable fertilizer components, thus contributing to a more sustainable nutrient cycle.
Beyond developing and refining its core technology, Movanta offers commercial-scale licensing of its HTU process along with technical support, engineering services, and operational guidance for clients across industries. Its solutions aim to support the circular economy and help industrial partners reduce their carbon footprint while addressing waste management challenges.

AtMoves primarily serves orthopedic surgeons and other healthcare providers involved in joint replacement procedures. items.about:
Lumetallix is a Dutch-leaning Amsterdam-based company offering a cutting-edge spray-on reagent and UV detection kit for identifying lead in household and industrial environments. Founded by scientists from the AMOLF Institute and the University of Amsterdam, the startup’s proprietary chemical formulation reacts exclusively with lead to create a fluorescent perovskite that glows bright green under UV light.

Designed to be fast, sensitive, and user-friendly, the Lumetallix kit can detect lead concentrations as low as 200 parts per million—equivalent to nanogram-level sensitivity—and is reportedly about 10,000 times more precise than standard colorimetric swab tests. Users simply apply the reagent, illuminate the area with the included UV light (“LeadLight”), and observe any glowing indications of lead presence in seconds.

The kit supports testing of a wide variety of materials—paint, ceramics, glass, plastics, metals, toys, pipes, soil, electronics and more—and has found applications in home safety, renovation work, consumer product inspection, and even forensic and environmental research. It comes with hundreds of test applications per refill, with both the reagent and testing process designed to be non-toxic and aviation-compliant for easy transport.

Lumetallix is led by co-founders with deep scientific and entrepreneurial backgrounds: a PhD chemist and a university professor-turned-inventor, alongside experienced operations and commercial leadership. The business distributes its products globally, reaches home users, professionals, and institutions, and collaborates with partners like Pure Earth and local authorities to enhance lead detection in vulnerable communities.

Keywords: Lumetallix, lead detection, fluorescent perovskite, UV kit, spray-on reagent, nanogram sensitivity, home safety, paint testing, forensics, environmental health, non-toxic testing, Amsterdam startup, AMOLF chemistry, user-friendly testing

items.about:
Eddytec is a Netherlands-based deep-tech startup founded in 2022, emerging as a spin-out from the University of Amsterdam and the Amsterdam University of Applied Sciences. The company specializes in precision non-destructive testing (NDT) solutions for carbon fibre composites—an area where defects like cracks and delamination pose significant challenges across sectors such as aerospace, automotive, prosthetics, and hydrogen storage.

Eddytec’s technology uses eddy currents to detect defects rapidly, accurately, and affordably. The method enables fast decision-making by delivering go/no-go results within minutes and generating 2D heatmaps across large areas in under ten minutes per square meter without requiring coupling agents.

The company offers two standout products designed for different inspection needs. EddySwift® is optimized for flat or gently curved surfaces, producing real-time 2D heatmaps with high speed and accuracy. It supports thicknesses up to 5 mm and integrates seamlessly with data analysis software for instant insight. EddyPen® is a compact handheld device designed for precision probing of complex geometries such as edges, corners, or intricate curves. It delivers immediate feedback and enables defect decisions even in tight or challenging zones.

Beyond hardware, Eddytec also provides NDT-as-a-service, allowing customers to send composite parts to its facility for expert inspection. This service generates detailed visual reports and data-driven recommendations, extending the company’s reach to clients who prefer outsourcing specialized testing.

The growing demand for quick, reliable carbon composite testing—especially in markets where traditional methods are time-consuming or semi-destructive—positions Eddytec as a cost-saving innovation partner. Applications include reducing waste in prosthetics manufacturing, speeding up damage assessments in aviation, and enabling fast testing of hydrogen pressure vessels.

Founded and led by a multidisciplinary team, Eddytec includes notable figures such as Dr. Alina Chanaewa (CEO), Dr. Rudolf Sprik, and Dr. Christiaan Schoemaker. The team brings strong academic roots and commercial expertise, backed by support from Innovatiefonds Noord-Holland and the venture arms of UvA and HvA.

Keywords: Eddytec, non-destructive testing, carbon fibre composites, eddy currents, EddySwift®, EddyPen®, rapid defect detection, NDT-as-a-service, carbon composite inspection, aerospace, prosthetics, hydrogen storage vessels, deep-tech spin-out, Amsterdam startup

items.about:
Rapid Photonics, a spin-off from the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam founded in 2022, is focused on advancing the fabrication of photonic integrated circuits (PICs). The company, co-founded by Steven Tan, is situated at the Science Park in Amsterdam. It operates within the semiconductor and photonics market, specifically targeting the production challenges associated with thin-film lithium niobate (TFLN), a material recognized for its potential in next-generation applications like ultra-high-speed datacom, quantum computing, and AI.

The core of Rapid Photonics' business is its patented production technology, DEpicT® (Direct Etch-less photonic integrated circuits Technology). This process is designed to overcome the traditional difficulties of manufacturing PICs on lithium niobate on insulator (LNOI) wafers. The technology enables the creation of low-loss waveguides with high yield, aiming to provide customers with a faster and more affordable path for design iterations, reducing lead times to a matter of weeks. The business model centers on providing fabrication services and collaborating with partners for the electrical and optical integration, packaging, and testing of PICs. Its clientele consists of PIC developers who can use the service to create components for applications such as high-frequency modulators, quantum optics, and neuromorphic photonic circuits.

The DEpicT® technology is 100% CMOS compatible, which allows for production to be scaled up in conventional silicon PIC foundries. Rapid Photonics' offerings support the integration of various passive and active photonic components, including Mach-Zehnder modulators, ring resonators, and couplers. The company is also developing other active components like surface acoustic wave modulators and amplifiers. A key benefit of their technology is its applicability to silicon nitrate PICs as well, offering competitive costs and shorter lead times. In March and April of 2024, the company secured €300,000 in a convertible loan from Innovatiefonds Noord-Holland to further develop its technology and create a demonstrator for the telecommunications market.

Keywords: photonic integrated circuits, lithium niobate, PIC fabrication, LNOI, DEpicT, semiconductor manufacturing, datacom, quantum computing, photonic components, waveguide fabrication, CMOS compatible, etchless production, silicon nitrate PICs, optical integration, neuromorphic circuits, high-frequency modulators, Amsterdam, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, Steven Tan, Innovatiefonds Noord-Holland

Vector search is a method that uses mathematical vectors to represent data, making it easier to find and retrieve information based on its meaning rather than just keywords. Weaviate operates in the artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) market, providing solutions that integrate seamlessly with popular AI frameworks such as OpenAI, Huggingface Transformers, and Jina AI's neural search framework. The open-source version allows users full control and relies on community support, while the managed service provides direct support from solution engineers, making it ideal for enterprises that require robust Service Level Agreements (SLAs) for production environments.

The business model of Weaviate revolves around offering its managed service to enterprises. By subscribing to the Weaviate Cluster Service, clients receive a fully managed, production-ready environment that includes direct support and infrastructure management. This subscription-based model ensures a steady revenue stream for the company.

Weaviate serves a diverse range of clients, from small startups to large enterprises, particularly those in sectors like eCommerce, healthcare, and finance, where advanced search capabilities can provide a competitive edge. The company makes money through subscription fees for its managed services, offering different pricing tiers based on the level of support and infrastructure required.

In summary, Weaviate is a promising player in the AI and ML market, providing advanced vector search capabilities through both open-source and managed service offerings. Its business model focuses on subscription-based revenue from enterprises needing reliable and scalable search solutions.

items.about:
Coolgradient is a Dutch company established to address the significant and growing energy consumption of data centers. Founded in Amsterdam in 2023 by Jasper de Vries and René Gompel, the firm provides an AI-driven software-as-a-service (SaaS) platform designed to optimize data center operations, with a particular focus on cooling and power infrastructure. The founders' backgrounds are complementary; de Vries has extensive experience in machine learning and data-driven solutions, including founding an AI edtech company, while Gompel brings over two decades of leadership experience in director and partner roles. Their collaboration began several years prior at ViaConnect Group, a consultancy that utilized AI to enhance data center sustainability. 

The company's business model is centered on its AI software solution that helps data center operators reduce energy and water consumption. It targets data center executives, operations leaders, and portfolio managers. The platform integrates with a facility's existing data points without the need for additional hardware or IoT projects, analyzing information from the entire infrastructure, from the 'roof-to-room'. By leveraging machine learning models trained on billions of data points, Coolgradient identifies inefficiencies in systems like chillers, cooling towers, and CRAHs. It then provides automated, prioritized recommendations and quantifies potential savings, which can be as high as 40% for energy and 25% for water. This holistic view allows for the harmonization of all operational assets, distinguishing it from solutions that focus on isolated components. 

The service provides a single interface, or 'single pane of glass', for monitoring the entire data center ecosystem, from a portfolio-wide perspective down to individual assets. This enables clients to proactively address operational risks, reduce costs, and improve sustainability metrics like Power Usage Effectiveness (PUE) and Water Usage Effectiveness (WUE). Furthermore, the software assists with automated compliance reporting for regulations such as the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) and the Energy Efficiency Directive (EED). Following a seed funding round in May 2024 led by 4impact capital, Coolgradient is focused on international expansion. 

Keywords: data center optimization, AI software, energy efficiency, data center cooling, power infrastructure, sustainability, machine learning, PUE optimization, WUE optimization, operational analytics, facility management software, ESG reporting, asset reliability, predictive maintenance, resource management, green data center, infrastructure optimization, energy consumption reduction, water savings, portfolio management

items.about:
LUMICKS is a life science tools company that develops and commercializes instruments for dynamic single-molecule and cell avidity analysis, enabling academic and biopharma researchers to get a deeper understanding of the fundamental mechanisms of biology and the drivers of disease. The company was established in 2014 as a spin-off from the Vrije Universiteit (VU) Amsterdam, founded by Olivier Heyning, Andrea Candelli, and Gijs Wuite. The founders' backgrounds are deeply rooted in biophysics; Gijs Wuite is a professor and head of the physics of living systems department at VU Amsterdam, while Olivier Heyning and Andrea Candelli both hold PhDs in the field, bringing a wealth of scientific and business development experience to the venture. 

The company's core business revolves around providing sophisticated instruments that allow researchers to analyze complex biological interactions in real-time. These tools are built upon Nobel Prize-winning technologies, specifically optical tweezers and super-resolution microscopy. This technological foundation allows LUMICKS' products to measure the forces and interactions between single molecules and cells, a capability that bridges the gap between structural biology and functional outcomes. The company's flagship products include the C-Trap®, which integrates optical tweezers with microfluidics and fluorescence microscopy, and the z-Movi®, a cell avidity analyzer. These instruments serve a client base that includes top universities, research institutes, and leading pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies. The business model is based on the sale of these high-value instruments and associated consumables, as well as providing support and services. 

LUMICKS' technology provides direct, real-time analysis of biological mechanisms, which is a significant advantage in fields like immuno-oncology, immunology, and genetic editing. For instance, the z-Movi® instrument can measure the binding strength (avidity) between immune cells and cancer cells, providing crucial insights for the development of new immunotherapies. This allows researchers to directly link a molecule's structure to its function at a granular level. The company has achieved significant milestones, including a major financing round of $93 million in 2021 to accelerate its commercial expansion, particularly in the immuno-oncology and drug development markets. This funding has supported the scaling of its operations and the expansion of its product portfolio, solidifying its position in the life sciences and diagnostics market.

Keywords: single-molecule analysis, cell avidity, optical tweezers, biophysics, life science tools, immuno-oncology, drug development, super-resolution microscopy, molecular biology, scientific instruments

Allergios is currently in the process of perfecting its solution and validating it in real clinical settings. By offering a more accurate and efficient diagnostic tool, Allergios aims to capture a significant share of the allergy diagnostics market.

In summary, Allergios is poised to revolutionize allergy diagnostics with its innovative technology, targeting healthcare providers who require precise and reliable diagnostic tools. The company is actively working on bringing its solution to market and securing the necessary funding to support its growth.

Omni Wind is a developer of compact wind turbine systems engineered for localized renewable energy generation in both urban and rural settings. The company was co-founded in 2021 by Pranav Tetali (CEO), Ruby Hsiao (CFO), and Kathy Vredeveldt. The systems are designed for modular integration with solar panels, batteries, and hydrogen systems, allowing for adaptable configurations that meet specific energy needs and help reduce reliance on centralized power grids. Hadrian.io is a cybersecurity startup that provides an advanced end-to-end offensive security platform. The company's primary focus is on identifying and mitigating external risks that could be exploited by hackers. Hadrian.io serves a broad range of clients, including market leaders who trust the platform to secure their digital assets.

The company operates in the cybersecurity market, a sector that is increasingly important as businesses continue to digitize their operations. Hadrian.io's business model revolves around its External Attack Surface Management (EASM) features, Continuous Autonomous Red Teaming (CART) capabilities, and Continuous Threat Exposure Management (CTEM) platform. 

EASM helps businesses identify every digital asset that could be a potential target for hackers. It continuously monitors for new assets and configuration changes that could put the organization at risk. CART prevents exposed risks from being exploited by hackers, focusing on the risks most likely to have the greatest business impact. The CTEM platform streamlines security workflows and reduces risk by replacing cumbersome point solutions.

Hadrian.io makes money by offering these cybersecurity services to businesses. The company's key use cases include continuous asset discovery, accurate vulnerability management, automated penetration testing, and 3rd party risk assessment. The platform can detect over 10,000 3rd party SaaS applications and thousands of different software packages, making it a comprehensive solution for businesses looking to secure their digital assets.

Tective Robotics specializes in autonomous drone solutions designed to provide continuous aerial data without direct operator handling. The company's core product, SkyHive, is a drone-in-a-box system that automates the entire drone workflow, including take-off, landing, and battery swapping, enabling 24/7 operation of a drone swarm. This system is designed to significantly increase the data acquisition capabilities for a single operator.

The company offers several tailored solutions based on its technology. SkyBase focuses on automated perimeter monitoring for areas up to 25 square kilometers. SkyFence is engineered for automated border mapping and live threat detection over hundreds of kilometers. For the agricultural sector, SkyScope provides high-precision data for early disease and pest detection at the plant level.

Tective Robotics was founded in 2021 by Jeroen van den Berg and Matthijs van den Berg. Jeroen, the CEO, has a background in Business Administration and previously founded a media company. Matthijs, the CTO, is a former naval officer with expertise in autonomous systems and robotics. Their combined experience drives the company's development of practical and advanced autonomous aerial systems. The company operates in markets such as security, infrastructure inspection, agriculture, and logistics.

Keywords: drone-in-a-box, autonomous drones, aerial data acquisition, perimeter security, agricultural technology, infrastructure monitoring, automated surveillance, robotics, drone swarm, precision agriculture

Annogen is a biotech startup based in Amsterdam that specializes in the development and provision of SuRE™ Promoters and AIM™ Integration Sites. These are essentially tools used for controlled gene expression in cell and gene therapy, protein and virus production. The company's primary clients are pharmaceutical and agricultural firms, as well as gene therapy companies. 

Annogen's business model revolves around the creation and improvement of its SuRE™ platform. This platform is used to study and manipulate gene expression, a critical process in the development of new therapies and treatments. The company generates revenue by providing its platform and related services to other companies in the biotech and pharmaceutical industries. 

Recently, Annogen has signed a deal with an undisclosed gene therapy company to use its SuRE™ libraries for in-vivo capsid screening. This project involves delivering its SuRE™ barcoding platform and downstream bioinformatics analysis to track tissue-specific biases for many capsids in parallel. 

In addition to this, Annogen has also introduced HEK293-INDX1™, a clonal HEK293 cell line for inducible expression of toxic proteins such as Rep during AAV production. This is a significant development in the field of gene therapy and protein production. 

The company is led by founder Joris van Arensbergen and biotech entrepreneur Victor Schut. They have a team of highly skilled scientists and technicians dedicated to their clients' projects and the continuous improvement of the SuRE™ platform.

Keywords: Biotech, Gene Therapy, Pharmaceutical Industry, Agricultural Industry, SuRE™ Promoters, AIM™ Integration Sites, Controlled Gene Expression, Protein Production, Virus Production, Capsid Screening.

items.about:
Amplio Pharma is a pharmaceutical company founded in May 2023 in the Netherlands, developing improved versions of existing drugs through its proprietary NovoBioJect / NovoBioMed platform. The company was founded by Charlott Brunmark, Marguerite Mensonides, and Karin von Wachenfeldt, three experienced life science entrepreneurs whose collaboration began over two decades ago at AstraZeneca. Their combined expertise in pharmacology, pharmacy, and immunology laid the foundation for Amplio Pharma’s core technology.

The company’s Modified Retention Technology enhances the efficacy of cornerstone drugs by preventing them from being expelled too quickly from target cells. Its lead candidate applies this approach to low-dose Methotrexate, the main treatment for rheumatoid arthritis and other immune-mediated inflammatory diseases (IMIDs). By adding novobiocin as a pharmacokinetic booster, the platform aims to increase Methotrexate’s success rate from roughly 30% to up to 70% of patients — improving clinical outcomes while reducing development risks, costs, and timelines through reformulation of an established drug.

Amplio Pharma operates as a lean, virtual organisation, with an experienced management team outsourcing implementation to Contract Research Organisations (CROs) and collaborating with universities such as Amsterdam UMC. The company’s strategy focuses on securing patents — already granted in Europe and the US — and licensing or selling its enhanced drug candidates to larger pharmaceutical partners for commercialisation.

Amplio Pharma has raised seed funding from Libertatis Ergo Holding, UvA Ventures Holding, and Innovatiefonds Noord-Holland.

Keywords: drug retention technology, rheumatoid arthritis treatment, methotrexate enhancement, autoimmune diseases, drug reformulation, novobiocin, pharmacokinetic booster, modified retention technology, clinical-stage biotech, pharmaceutical development, inflammatory diseases, IMIDs, drug discovery

items.about:
HypherData is a startup focused on providing synthetic data services specifically for the life sciences sector. Synthetic data is artificially generated data that mimics real-world data but does not contain any actual personal information, making it highly secure and ethical for use. The company operates by connecting data providers—those who have valuable data to offer—with data seekers—those who need this data for various purposes such as research, analysis, and development.

HypherData serves clients in the life sciences industry, including pharmaceutical companies, research institutions, and healthcare organizations. These clients require high-quality data to drive their artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) models, but often face challenges related to data privacy and security. HypherData addresses these challenges by offering synthetic data that is statistically equivalent to real data, ensuring it is both accurate and robust.

The company operates in the synthetic data market, which is a niche but rapidly growing segment within the broader data services and AI markets. HypherData's business model revolves around creating a marketplace where data requests and offers can be submitted confidentially and securely. The platform matches data providers with data seekers, facilitating transactions that are both ethical and risk-free.

HypherData makes money by charging fees for its matchmaking services and potentially taking a commission on data transactions. By building a comprehensive database and a robust partner network, the company aims to create a thriving data ecosystem where synthetic data can be easily accessed, shared, and monetized.

In summary, HypherData is a pioneering company in the synthetic data services market for life sciences, offering a secure and ethical way to share and monetize data. It serves as a crucial link between data providers and seekers, ensuring that valuable data can be used without compromising privacy.

Keywords: Synthetic Data, Life Sciences, AI, Data Privacy, Data Security, Data Marketplace, Data Monetization, Ethical Data, Data Sharing, Data Analysis.

VectorY operates within the biotechnology and pharmaceutical sectors, focusing on research and development (R&D) to create its therapies. The company invests heavily in R&D to identify promising antibody and gene therapy combinations, which are then developed into treatments that can be brought to market.

Revenue generation for VectorY comes from multiple streams. Primarily, the company earns money through the commercialization of its developed therapies, either by selling them directly to healthcare providers or through partnerships with larger pharmaceutical companies. Additionally, VectorY may engage in licensing agreements, where other companies pay for the rights to use its proprietary technologies and therapies. This diversified approach helps ensure a steady flow of income while advancing its mission to improve patient outcomes.

In summary, VectorY is a biotech startup dedicated to creating innovative, long-lasting therapies for patients with significant medical needs by combining antibodies and gene therapy. items.about:
Context Labs offers a climate analytics platform focused on sourcing, organizing, and contextualizing global climate information. Founded in 2012 by Dan Harple, a serial entrepreneur and MIT Sloan Fellow, the company originated from research at MIT. Harple, who has been a key figure in developing various internet standards, initially envisioned the company as a platform to combat online misinformation but pivoted its focus to environmental data around 2018. The firm targets industries critical to the energy transition, including oil and gas, utilities, and large industrial operators, providing them with verifiable emissions data. 

The company's business model is centered on providing its platform and layered services to enterprises, likely on a subscription or usage basis, to help them manage and report on their environmental impact. Its core technology is the Immutably™ Enterprise Data Fabric, a platform that uses AI, machine learning, and blockchain to ingest data from diverse sources—such as satellites, drones, and on-site sensors—and transform it into trusted, unalterable "Asset Grade Data" (AGD™). This process creates a verifiable, auditable trail of environmental data, addressing the problem of data fragmentation and inaccuracy in emissions reporting. 

Built upon the Immutably™ fabric, Context Labs has deployed two primary service layers. The first is Decarbonization-as-a-Service™ (DaaS™), which gives clients a digital twin of their operations to identify emission sources and quantify the carbon intensity of their products. The second is the CLEAR Path™ platform, which is designed to increase transparency and trust in environmental commodities markets by creating high-quality, verifiable carbon credits and other environmental attributes. The company has formed strategic partnerships with major firms like Microsoft, KPMG, Encino, and Satlantis to integrate its technology and expand its reach. In February 2022, Context Labs announced it had raised $28 million from investors including BP Energy Partners and Equinor Ventures to further its decarbonization solutions. 

Keywords: climate analytics, asset grade data, decarbonization-as-a-service, carbon accounting, environmental commodities, emissions quantification, enterprise data fabric, blockchain, Dan Harple, Immutably, CLEAR Path, DaaS, energy transition, GHG emissions reporting, environmental data verification, carbon credits, MIT research, ESG data, climate tech, sustainability software

Photosynthetic B.V. is a deep-tech company revolutionizing the microfabrication industry with a novel 3D printing technology. Founded in 2018 by Alexander Kostenko as a spin-off from the Centrum Wiskunde & Informatica (CWI), the company is developing a hardware solution for printing 3D structures at the micron level. Kostenko, who holds a PhD in Applied Physics, conceived the technology while working on a project involving imaging cultural heritage, leading to the creation of Photosynthetic. 

The company's patented technology is based on Volumetric Lithography, a process that uses a light-controlled chemical reaction to fabricate objects. This method allows for the creation of true 3D structures with sub-micron feature sizes at high speeds, a significant advancement over current technologies that rely on stacking 2D layers. The process aims to make microfabrication faster and more affordable, reducing development times from months to days. This enables rapid prototyping and mass production of complex microstructures. 

Photosynthetic serves high-tech industries requiring microscopic components, such as healthcare, life sciences, automotive, and optics. Its technology is applied in the production of Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) and Lab-on-a-Chip devices. The business model centers on providing this advanced manufacturing platform to partners and customers for both prototyping and industrial production. The company has received funding from entities including the Innovation Fund North Holland, which provided a convertible loan of €300,000, and received a Eurostars grant. 

Keywords: microfabrication, 3D printing, Volumetric Lithography, additive manufacturing, MEMS, lab-on-a-chip, micron-level printing, rapid prototyping, high-resolution printing, deep-tech, hardware, photonics, microstructures, advanced manufacturing, submicron resolution, medical devices, optics, computational imaging, nanotechnology, material science

Veridis is a pioneering startup focused on revolutionizing the plastic recycling industry. The company has developed advanced thermal analysis technology that provides a reliable "material fingerprint" for recycled plastics, including dark plastics, which are notoriously difficult to analyze accurately. This innovation addresses a significant gap in the market, as dark plastics represent at least 10% of all plastics and are often relegated to low-quality applications or incinerated due to the inability to assess their quality properly.

Veridis primarily serves recycling companies and other stakeholders in the plastic supply chain who require precise quality control to enhance the commercial value of recycled plastics. By offering a solution that reduces uncertainty in the recycled plastic material stream by at least tenfold, Veridis enables these companies to compete more effectively with producers of new plastics. This not only improves the economic viability of recycling but also contributes to a more transparent and efficient market with less friction.

Operating in the global plastic recycling market, Veridis employs a business model centered around the sale and deployment of its plastic analysis machines. The company generates revenue through direct sales of these machines, as well as potential service agreements for ongoing maintenance and updates. By increasing the reliability and value of recycled plastics, Veridis directly impacts the bottom line of its clients, making its technology an essential tool for modern recycling operations.

In summary, Veridis is at the forefront of "Recycling 2.0," offering a groundbreaking solution that enhances the quality and marketability of recycled plastics, particularly dark plastics. This not only helps reduce the environmental impact of plastic waste but also supports the economic sustainability of the recycling industry.

Laser Precision Solutions (LPS) is a pioneering company specializing in innovative railway maintenance technology. The company has developed the LaserTrain, a specialized cleaning wagon designed to tackle the issue of low adhesion on railways caused by falling leaves and other debris. This problem often leads to delays and increased maintenance costs for railway operators.

LPS primarily serves railway companies and transit authorities, with a notable partnership with the Long Island Rail Road (LIRR) in the United States. The company operates in the railway maintenance market, which is crucial for ensuring the efficiency and safety of rail transport systems.

The business model of LPS revolves around leasing its LaserTrain technology to railway operators. The LaserTrain is fully autonomous, requiring no operator, and can be attached to existing locomotives. It uses laser technology to clean the tracks, providing a cleaning effect that lasts for 24 hours. This innovative solution has proven to increase punctuality by 2.0% and reduce the fleet out of service by 50%. Additionally, the maintenance reduction offsets the cost of leasing the LaserTrain, making it a cost-effective solution for railway operators.

LPS makes money through leasing agreements with railway companies. These agreements typically span multiple years, providing a steady revenue stream. The company also benefits from the cost savings and efficiency improvements its technology offers to clients, which makes the LaserTrain an attractive investment for railway operators.

In summary, Laser Precision Solutions is revolutionizing railway maintenance with its LaserTrain technology, offering a sustainable, efficient, and cost-effective solution to the problem of low adhesion on tracks. The company is actively scaling up and seeking new talent to expand its operations and continue its growth trajectory.

Keywords: LaserTrain, railway maintenance, low adhesion, autonomous cleaning, cost-effective, efficiency, sustainability, leasing model, railway operators, innovation.

SpectriS-dot BV is a Dutch startup that specializes in the development of non-toxic semiconductor quantum dots, also known as SQ-dots. These are tiny particles of semiconductors with special coatings that can emit light in a very efficient and adjustable way. The company's SQ-dots are primarily made of silicon, a non-toxic and abundant element, making them a safer and more sustainable alternative to the hazardous or expensive materials currently used in quantum dots.

The company's products have a wide range of applications, including security and surveillance, UV-coatings, bio-functional coatings for sensing, medical imaging, drug delivery, renewable energy, quantum optics and photonics, LEDs, and color displays for various devices. This broad market potential positions SpectriS-dot BV to serve a diverse client base, from healthcare providers to electronics manufacturers and renewable energy companies.

The business model of SpectriS-dot BV revolves around the production and sale of these SQ-dots. The company leverages the existing silicon production technology and infrastructure, which is well-developed due to its common use in microelectronics and photovoltaics. This allows for cost-effective scalability without major economic, environmental, or health consequences.

In summary, SpectriS-dot BV is a promising startup that offers a safer, more sustainable, and versatile alternative to traditional quantum dots. Its products have the potential to revolutionize a variety of industries, from healthcare to electronics, while also contributing to environmental sustainability.

Keywords: Quantum Dots, Non-Toxic, Silicon, Semiconductor, Sustainability, Scalability, Versatility, Bio-Functional Coatings, LEDs, Color Displays.
items.name: Spectris-Dot
items.tagline: Development of non-toxic semiconductor quantum dots (SQ-dots) with efficient, tunable emission

items.about:
WSK Medical focuses on developing AI solutions for real-time detection and classification of Head and Neck cancers during a routine endoscopic examination. Zeno AI (CE-MDR class IIb approved) is the first AI solution on the market for the real-time detection and classification of benign lesions and cancer in the Head and Neck area for Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT). Currently being used by Radboudumc, UMC Groningen, and more, Zeno AI provides ENT surgeons real-time assistance in detection and classification of benign or malignant lesions at an early stage during a routine endoscopic examination. Zeno AI aims to provide ENT clinicians and - in the future - first line clinicians - the expert knowledge of Head and Neck oncology surgeons in the form of a plug-and-play, vendor agnostic AI solution that works as simple as an overlay on the endoscopic screen. Join our journey today by enabling faster, better and more precise care for Head and Neck cancers.   

WSK Medical's business model revolves around building bespoke machine learning systems tailored to the specific needs of their clients. They offer end-to-end solutions, from prototype development to full-scale production systems. The company generates revenue through the sale of these custom AI systems, as well as through partnerships and collaborations with medical institutions.

The company is deeply committed to data preparation, ensuring that datasets are cleansed, relevant, and reconstructed to meet the requirements of their models. This meticulous approach to data handling is crucial for the accuracy and reliability of their AI systems.

In summary, WSK Medical is at the forefront of integrating AI into healthcare, with a strong focus on early cancer detection. Their innovative solutions have the potential to save lives by enabling earlier and more accurate diagnoses.

Keywords: AI diagnostics, cancer detection, machine learning, healthcare technology, ENT, head and neck oncology, head and neck cancer, detection, classification

items.tagline: WSK Medical is the first and only company that have developed and launched (CE-MDR class IIb approved) an AI solution that is able to detect and classify head and neck cancer during an endoscopy in real-time

Seaborough, a pioneering LED technology firm, specializes in the development, commercialization, and licensing of cutting-edge lighting solutions across three key domains: Electronics, Life Science, and Materials.

In the realm of Electronics, our focus lies in advancing the adoption of LED lighting. Our flagship product, OneTLed, revolutionizes the industry by offering a versatile LED solution that seamlessly replaces mercury-laden fluorescent tubes (T8) across 99% of existing ballasts and fixtures. Further enhancing our electronic portfolio is Ultima, a patented disruptive technology that significantly amplifies the positive impacts of LED retrofit tubes on both business performance and environmental sustainability.

Within our Life Science division, we prioritize the advancement of healthy lighting solutions for medical and preventive healthcare applications. SunLED, our latest innovation, brings the health benefits of natural sunlight indoors, positively influencing the well-being of individuals who spend extended periods indoors.

In the Materials program, our focus centers on research and development to engineer highly efficient phosphors tailored for LED applications. Renowned as a trusted partner within the lighting industry, Seaborough boasts an exceptional R&D department collaborating with premier universities and institutes, alongside regular publication of scientific findings.

At our core, we are dedicated to inventing, developing, and commercializing groundbreaking innovations that prioritize sustainability within the lighting sector. Our mission is to produce top-tier products that not only excel in performance but also contribute positively to the environment.

Established in 2013 and headquartered in Amsterdam, Seaborough continues to lead the way in revolutionizing the lighting industry.

items.about:
Bambooder Biobased Fibers B.V., established in 2021 by entrepreneurs Laurens Treur and Thijs van den Munckhof, operates from Wageningen, Netherlands, with a focus on developing sustainable materials. The company has positioned itself within the biobased economy, specifically targeting the replacement of conventional, fossil-fuel-based plastics and glass fibers with a more environmentally friendly alternative derived from bamboo. Treur's background includes experience as a project manager in sustainable energy and as a business developer at a food-tech company, while van den Munckhof brings expertise from his prior role as an R&D project manager, reflecting a blend of commercial and technical acumen driving the venture. 
The core of Bambooder's business is the production and supply of bamboo fiber, a material engineered to enhance the properties of bio-plastics. This fiber is designed to be integrated into plastic compounds, resulting in materials that are not only stronger and stiffer but also lighter than traditional plastics. The company's business model revolves around supplying these bamboo fibers to plastic compounders and producers who serve various industries, including automotive, consumer goods, and construction. By providing a raw material that improves the performance and sustainability profile of their clients' end products, Bambooder generates revenue through the sale of its specialized bamboo fibers. A significant milestone for the company was securing a €530,000 pre-seed investment in 2023, led by the Stichting Boralis, to advance its research, development, and production capabilities. 
The primary product offered by Bambooder is a specially treated bamboo fiber that exhibits superior mechanical properties, making it a viable reinforcement agent for bio-based and conventional polymers. The production process involves sourcing bamboo, a fast-growing and resource-efficient crop, and processing it into fibers that can be seamlessly blended with plastics. The key benefit for their clients is the ability to create more sustainable and higher-performing products, addressing the growing market demand for green materials without compromising on quality. Bambooder's unique selling proposition lies in its focus on bamboo as a high-performance, sustainable alternative to glass fiber and other fossil-based fillers, contributing to the circular economy. 
Keywords: bamboo fiber, bioplastics, sustainable materials, biobased economy, material science, plastic compounding, circular economy, cleantech, biomaterials, green manufacturing
items.name: Bambooder
items.tagline: Bambooder produces and develops bio-based fibers that will fully or partly replace minerals for renewable bio-based raw materials in order to create new applications for the composite industry

items.about:
SuperSeton, a venture-capital-backed company headquartered in Amsterdam, is focused on advancing the treatment of perianal fistulas. Founded in 2017, the company emerged from a joint initiative between the Amsterdam University Medical Centre, Medishield, and the health tech venture builder NLC. The core team includes CEO Ernst Elhorst, CTO Willem Nerkens, and inventor Dr. Tim Horeman. The company addresses a long-standing issue in proctology: traditional setons, used for draining fistulas, rely on a knot for closure which often causes significant pain, irritation, and discomfort for patients, thereby limiting their quality of life.

SuperSeton has developed a medical device that replaces the conventional knot with a patented, smooth, and secure closure mechanism. This design aims to reduce patient discomfort and complications, potentially lowering hospital visits and associated costs. The product consists of the knotless seton and a disposable applicator that allows for manual, quick, and simple application by a medical professional, fitting seamlessly into established medical practices. The device is engineered to be entirely smooth, preventing the irritation caused by the bulky knots of traditional setons.

The company's business model revolves around the sale of this patented medical device to healthcare institutions, specifically targeting colorectal surgeons and proctologists. SuperSeton has established a distribution network across Europe, with partners in the Benelux region, Germany, Austria, the UK, Ireland, and the Nordic countries. The product has received CE certification, permitting its sale within the European market, and the company has filed for patent protection in Europe, the USA, and Asia. The company has successfully raised capital through multiple funding rounds, including a Series A in March 2018 and subsequent venture funding, to support its commercial expansion and product development.

Keywords: perianal fistula treatment, knotless seton, medical device, proctology, coloproctology, fistula drainage, surgical supplies, Amsterdam UMC spin-off, patient comfort, healthcare innovation, medtech, therapeutic devices, CE marked medical device, surgical instruments, minimally invasive, NLC venture builder, EIT Health

items.about:
ChainCraft is a pioneering startup operating in the sustainable chemicals industry. The company's innovative approach involves creating circular chemicals from food waste, a process that is not only eco-friendly but also contributes to the circular economy. This is a significant departure from the traditional reliance on petrochemicals and palm oil, which are non-renewable, environmentally destructive, and potentially harmful to human health.

The company's primary clients are in the agri-food and chemical & material industries. ChainCraft's products, specifically medium-chain fatty acids (MCFAs), are produced naturally through non-GMO fermentation of food waste. These bio-based chemicals are a reliable and sustainable alternative to traditional chemicals, offering consistent quality and performance.

ChainCraft's business model is centered on the concept of "upcycling" food waste. This involves transforming waste into valuable products, in this case, bio-based chemicals. The company's advanced chain elongation technology enables it to achieve net-zero production of chemicals, contributing to a more resilient and sustainable future.

In terms of revenue generation, ChainCraft likely sells its bio-based chemicals to businesses in the agri-food and chemical & material industries. By providing a sustainable and high-quality alternative to traditional chemicals, the company is well-positioned to capitalize on the growing demand for eco-friendly solutions in these sectors.

Keywords: ChainCraft, sustainable chemicals, food waste, circular economy, bio-based chemicals, medium-chain fatty acids, non-GMO fermentation, upcycling, chain elongation technology, agri-food industry.

items.about:
Neurocast is a digital health company, founded in 2017, that provides a platform for passive brain health monitoring. The firm operates in the digital health and decision/risk analysis market, targeting its services towards pharmaceutical companies for clinical trials and academic research. In the future, it plans to offer its software for prescription by healthcare providers to patients with brain-related diseases. The company generates revenue by providing its clinically validated platform for collecting real-world data on participants' brain health remotely and non-invasively. 

The company was founded by Levie Hofstee, who currently serves as CEO. Neurocast is headquartered in Amsterdam, Netherlands, with an office in Cambridge, Massachusetts. A significant milestone was achieved in May 2025, when the company registered its passive monitoring platform with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) under a 510(k)-exempt classification, enabling its entry into the U.S. market, starting with multiple sclerosis. The company has secured $2.75 million in funding from investors including EIT Health and Johnson & Johnson Innovation - JLABS. It has also won several international awards, including the EIT Health Neurotech prize in 2022. 

Neurocast's core product is a software platform, known as NeuroKeys, that functions as a digital biomarker. It replaces the standard keyboard on a user's smartphone with an intelligent keyboard that analyzes typing behavior, motion, and other digital interactions to gain insights into a person's motor and cognitive function. This allows for the continuous and unobtrusive collection of real-world data without requiring active input from the user or additional hardware. The platform captures subtle changes that may signal disease progression long before they are clinically apparent, providing early, personalized neurological insights. Data is collected anonymously with privacy and data security embedded by design; the platform analyzes *how* users interact with their device, not the content of their interactions, and is GDPR-compliant and ISO 27001-certified. Neurocast is also developing versions of its technology for computers and tablets. 

Keywords: passive patient monitoring, digital biomarkers, brain health, neuro-monitoring, clinical trials, digital health, remote patient monitoring, multiple sclerosis, neurological disorders, cognitive decline, motor function analysis, smartphone keyboard data, real-world data, FDA registered, NeuroKeys, Levie Hofstee, predictive health analytics, neurotech, Alzheimer's disease, mental health monitoring, psychiatric conditions, data-driven healthcare

items.about:
Aectual, a Dutch company founded in 2017, operates at the intersection of architecture, engineering, and construction (AEC) by providing a platform for customizable, 3D-printed architectural products. The company was established by architects Hans Vermeulen, Hedwig Heinsman, and Martine de Wit, who previously founded the architecture firm DUS Architects. Their journey began with the ambition to make architecture more accessible through digitalization, which led them to build their own large-scale 3D printer and launch the notable 3D Print Canal House project in 2013. This research-driven initiative garnered international attention and demonstrated the potential for 3D printing in construction, ultimately leading to the spin-off, Aectual.

The company's business model centers on a design-to-delivery platform that allows clients, primarily in the workplace, retail, and hospitality sectors, to create bespoke architectural and interior design products. Clients can either upload their own designs or customize parametric products from Aectual's portfolio, which includes flooring, wall panels, room dividers, planters, and even facades. Revenue is generated through the sale of these customizable products, which the company states can reduce costs by up to 50% and accelerate production times significantly compared to traditional custom manufacturing. Aectual serves a global clientele that includes prominent brands like Nike, BMW, Tiffany & Co, and has completed projects for locations such as Amsterdam Schiphol Airport.

Aectual’s core offering is its XL 3D printing service, which utilizes robotic arms and proprietary software to produce large-scale items. A key differentiator is its commitment to a circular economy. The company uses recycled and bio-based materials, such as plant-based plastics developed with Henkel, recycled drink cartons from Tetra Pak, and a recently developed material derived from wood waste. A cornerstone of this model is the 'take-back service', which allows customers to return used products. Aectual then shreds these items and reprints them into new products, offering customers a cashback incentive and ensuring materials can be reused multiple times. This process significantly reduces material waste and CO2 emissions, addressing a major challenge in the construction industry.

items.about:
Plantics positions itself as a key player in the biomaterials market, leveraging a patented technology originating from the University of Amsterdam. Founded in 2014 by Professor Gadi Rothenberg and Dr. Helias A. Udo de Haes, the company emerged as a university spin-off to commercialize a groundbreaking invention: the world's first 100% bio-based thermoset resins. The founders' backgrounds are deeply rooted in academia and sustainable science. Professor Rothenberg is a distinguished figure in Heterogeneous Catalysis and Sustainable Chemistry at the University of Amsterdam, with numerous patents and publications to his name. Dr. Udo de Haes is a professor emeritus in Environmental Sciences from Leiden University, with extensive experience in Life Cycle Assessment (LCA). 

The company's core business revolves around the development and production of these unique bio-resins, which are derived from plant-based waste materials like glycerol and citric acid. This process results in materials that are not only sourced from renewable biomass but are also CO2-negative, as the plant feedstocks absorb CO2 during their growth. Plantics operates on a business-to-business model, supplying its bio-polymers in various forms, such as granules or foams, to industrial partners. These partners then use the materials to manufacture end-products for various markets. Plantics' strategy involves co-developing new products and production processes with these partners, offering pilot-scale manufacturing and ongoing support to bring circular products to market. 

The product portfolio is centered on a family of circular, non-toxic, and biodegradable thermoset resins. Unlike traditional thermoset plastics, Plantics' materials are fully recyclable. The resins serve as a sustainable alternative to fossil fuel-based binders containing elements like formaldehyde and isocyanates. The primary applications for these resins are in the creation of composites, foams, and coatings. When combined with natural fibers such as hemp, the bio-resin creates strong, wood-like composites used for furniture, traffic signs, and decorative items. Notable product collaborations include the award-winning 'Hemp' chair collection with Vepa and 'Zero ThinPly' plywood with Koskisen. Other applications include biodegradable plant pots, circular wood panels for construction, and insulation foams. These products are designed to compete economically with conventional plastics, aiming to reduce the financial barrier for companies transitioning to sustainable materials.

items.about:
Pacmed, an Amsterdam-based healthcare technology firm founded in 2015, develops clinical decision support systems for hospitals. The company's genesis traces back to the 2014 Dutch National ThinkTank, where founders Wouter Kroese (a medical student), Willem Herter (a physicist), and Hidde Hovenkamp (an econometrician) were tasked with exploring how big data could improve society's health. This experience prompted them to dedicate their careers to applying AI to extensive clinical data to provide healthcare professionals with personalized patient insights. Their goal is to empower medical experts, not replace them, by creating a synergy between physicians and AI.

Pacmed's business model centers on providing hospitals with end-to-end AI solutions that integrate into their existing workflows. Serving as a partner, the company assists with implementation, offers continuous support, and helps tailor the technology to the specific needs of the medical institution. This collaborative approach aims to enhance clinical reasoning, automate administrative tasks, and optimize resource management, thereby reducing costs and easing the workload on healthcare professionals. The firm ensures its AI solutions are secure, compliant, reliable, and interpretable, working with medical experts to validate them for safe and effective clinical impact.

The company's flagship product is Pacmed Critical, an AI platform designed for Intensive Care Units (ICUs). This platform analyzes vast amounts of real-time and historical patient data—with one early algorithm drawing on 14 years of data from 16,000 ICU admissions—to predict patient outcomes. Specifically, it helps clinicians determine the optimal time for a patient's discharge by calculating the probability of readmission or death within seven days. The system presents this complex analysis through a user-friendly dashboard that visualizes key patient data, trends, and discharge readiness, translating machine learning outputs into clear, actionable information to support high-stakes decision-making. The technology initially saw use in primary care, assisting general practitioners with treatment decisions for urinary tract infections, before the company shifted its focus to the ICU, where it identified the most significant potential for impact.

Keywords: clinical decision support, healthcare AI, medical machine learning, ICU optimization, patient data analytics, predictive healthcare, clinical intelligence, hospital workflow integration, responsible AI, data-driven medicine, Amsterdam, Wouter Kroese, Willem Herter, Hidde Hovenkamp, Pacmed Critical, ICU discharge, physician support tools, health-tech, medical software, clinical outcomes

items.about:
InnoSeis B.V. operates at the forefront of seismic monitoring and geophysical exploration, originating as a spin-off from the Gravitational Physics Group at Nikhef, the Dutch National Institute for Subatomic Physics, in 2013. The company was founded by Dr. Mark Beker and Prof. Dr. Johannes van den Brand, who leveraged their research in seismicity and gravitational wave detection to create lightweight wireless seismic sensors for the energy industry. Based in Amsterdam, the company's initial mission was to address challenges in seismic data acquisition.

The company's first major product, a wireless seismic node called TremorNet, offered a smaller and easier-to-handle alternative to existing systems, simplifying the deployment of large sensor networks and reducing costs. This was followed by an improved version named Quantum, which was even lighter and more efficient, designed to scale to networks of up to one million nodes for high-resolution imaging. This product line proved highly successful, capturing a significant portion of the global seismic sensor market within three years before being sold to INOVA Geophysical Equipment Limited, which now has full control over the technology's development and commercialization. Following this sale, InnoSeis has continued to operate as an independent entity, focusing on developing next-generation technologies.

Pivoting its focus, the firm established InnoSeis Sensor Technologies B.V. to adapt its core physics research for broader applications. This new direction has led to the development of micro-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS) accelerometers. These sensors, born from gravitational wave detection research, offer high sensitivity in a small package, with low power consumption. They are designed for high-end inertial sensing applications in sectors that include autonomous vehicles, aerospace, defense, and infrastructure monitoring. The company's MEMS accelerometers are noted for their small size (9x9x3mm), light weight (1.5 grams), and low power consumption (as low as 20mW). InnoSeis Sensor Technologies is now enabling technologies that require sensitive and reliable motion data, with collaborations including a project with the European Space Agency that achieved a world record in sensor sensitivity.

Keywords: seismic sensors, MEMS accelerometers, geophysical exploration, wireless sensor networks, gravitational wave detection, inertial sensing, motion sensors, sensor technology, autonomous vehicles, aerospace applications, defense technology, infrastructure monitoring, low-power sensors, high-sensitivity sensors, geophysics, satellite positioning, deep-tech, Nikhef spin-off, Mark Beker, Johannes van den Brand

items.about:
Finch Buildings, established in 2014 by Jurrian Knijt, specializes in the development of modular and circular building systems. Knijt, with a background in architecture from TU Delft, founded the company based on his vision for sustainable and adaptable construction. The company's core focus is on creating buildings from solid wood, specifically cross-laminated timber (CLT), which is sourced from sustainably managed forests. This approach allows for a significant reduction in CO2 emissions compared to traditional construction methods using concrete and steel. 

The business operates by producing prefabricated modules that can be assembled on-site in a short period. These modules are designed to be adaptable, reusable, and even movable, catering to a market that demands flexibility and sustainability. Finch Buildings serves a diverse client base, including housing corporations, healthcare institutions, municipalities, and developers, providing solutions for residential housing, student accommodation, and care facilities. The revenue model is based on the sale of these modular buildings, offering a turnkey solution from design to installation.

The product itself is a system of wooden modules that can be configured in various ways to create different types of buildings. A key feature is their circularity; the buildings are designed to be disassembled and their components reused, minimizing waste and extending the material lifecycle. The solid wood construction provides a healthy indoor climate and has fire-resistant properties. This modular, circular, and bio-based construction method represents the company's distinct approach to addressing the demand for sustainable real estate development.

Keywords: modular construction, circular building, cross-laminated timber, sustainable real estate, prefabricated modules, bio-based materials, wooden buildings, sustainable architecture, real estate development, green building

SkinVision's market includes both direct-to-consumer (DTC) and business-to-business (B2B) segments. In the DTC segment, the app is marketed to individuals who are proactive about their skin health. In the B2B segment, SkinVision collaborates with healthcare providers, insurance companies, and corporate wellness programs to integrate its technology into broader health management systems.

The company differentiates itself through its clinically validated technology, partnerships with leading dermatologists, and a strong focus on user experience. By providing timely and accurate skin health assessments, SkinVision aims to reduce the incidence of late-stage skin cancer diagnoses and improve overall skin health outcomes.

items.about:
Skytree develops and manufactures decentralized direct air capture (DAC) technology that filters carbon dioxide from the ambient air. The company's core product is a modular CO2 capture unit, known as 'Cumulus', which can be integrated into various settings such as indoor farms, greenhouses, and buildings to provide a localized source of CO2. This process, based on a proprietary sorbent material, allows businesses to utilize the captured CO2 onsite for purposes like enhancing crop yields in controlled environment agriculture or for mineralization in building materials, thereby creating a circular carbon economy. The business model focuses on selling these CO2-generating units to clients in sectors like vertical farming and e-fuels, offering them a reliable and clean alternative to traditional, fossil fuel-based CO2 supply chains. 

Skytree was founded in 2014 by Max Beaumont as a spin-off from the European Space Agency (ESA), where the underlying DAC technology was initially developed for space applications, specifically for life support systems on the International Space Station. The technology was originally intended to purify the air for astronauts by removing CO2. The journey from space to Earth involved adapting this advanced technology to tackle terrestrial CO2 challenges. The company has secured significant funding to support its commercialization efforts, including a €6 million Series A round in 2022 led by Horticoop and Yield Lab Europe. This funding has enabled Skytree to expand its team, establish a new headquarters in Amsterdam, and scale up the production of its carbon capture units. 

Keywords: direct air capture, carbon capture, CO2 utilization, decentralized CO2 supply, cleantech, sorbent technology, circular carbon economy, controlled environment agriculture, space technology, climate tech

items.about:
Fastned, founded in February 2012 by Michiel Langezaal and Bart Lubbers, operates a rapidly expanding network of fast-charging stations for electric vehicles (EVs). The founders' journey began with a shared vision to enable long-distance electric travel. Langezaal, with a background in mechanical engineering and experience at the fast-charger manufacturer Epyon, and Lubbers, an entrepreneur and investor, combined their expertise to address the nascent EV market's need for a reliable charging infrastructure. Their direct experience with early EVs highlighted the critical lack of fast-charging options, which became the company's foundational mission. 

The company's core business is building and operating high-power charging (HPC) stations. Its primary clients are individual EV drivers and, increasingly, fleet operators. Fastned's business model is centered on selling electricity to these customers. Revenue is generated directly from charging fees, with options for ad-hoc payment via credit/debit card or through the Fastned app, which offers a subscription model (Gold Member) for a discounted rate per kWh. While the company has consistently grown its revenue, it has also posted net losses, a strategic decision attributed to its aggressive, ongoing expansion across Europe. 

Fastned's stations are a key differentiator. They are strategically located in high-traffic areas like highway rest stops and urban centers across several European countries, including the Netherlands, Germany, the UK, France, and Italy. The stations are designed for visibility and user comfort, often featuring a distinctive solar canopy that provides shelter and generates renewable energy. The network boasts high reliability, with an uptime of over 99.9%, and offers a seamless user experience through features like Autocharge, which automates payment once a vehicle is registered. The chargers support multiple standards, including CCS and CHAdeMO, and a majority of the charge points are rated for high-speed charging between 300 to 400kW, significantly reducing charging times. This focus on speed, reliability, and convenient locations underpins the company's value proposition to EV drivers.

items.about:
Avantium is a pioneering company that operates in the chemical technology sector, with a focus on sustainability and innovation. The company's mission is to create a fossil-free world by developing and commercializing innovative chemistry technologies. These technologies are used to produce chemicals and materials from renewable feedstock, replacing the traditional reliance on fossil resources. 

Avantium's primary clients are industries that require chemicals for their production processes, particularly those involved in the manufacture of consumer goods like plastics and textiles. The company's business model revolves around the development and sale of these innovative chemistry technologies, as well as providing research and development solutions in the field of sustainable chemistry. 

One of the ways Avantium makes money is by offering advanced catalyst testing technology and services, which help other companies speed up their catalyst research and development. This positions Avantium as a leading provider in this niche market. 

The company's flagship products are FDCA and plantMEG™, which are used to produce a novel type of plastic called PEF. This plastic is 100% plant-based, recyclable, and boasts superior performance features. Avantium is also working on several other technologies that are in the pre-pilot phase or beyond, demonstrating its commitment to continuous innovation.

In conclusion, Avantium is a forward-thinking company that is driving the transition to a fossil-free world through its innovative chemistry technologies. It serves a broad range of industries and has a strong focus on sustainability and innovation.

Keywords: Chemical Technology, Sustainability, Innovation, Renewable Feedstock, Catalyst Testing, Consumer Goods, FDCA, plantMEG™, PEF Plastic, Fossil-Free.
